6/ How can we identify or create anti-fragile systems? How can we defend against the broken Lindy effect?

{fin}

1064548341621567494.text:
5/ What this means is, something once thought safe, actually becomes unsafe when it gets big

Electoral college worked fine for awhile until manipulation at scale become feasible and highly valuable

Often it works to prolong the life of the system, making it at lesser robust.

1064546062822600704.text:
4/ Awhile back, I thought of a corollary I call “The Broken Lindy Effect”

The longer something has been around, the harder it is to fix if it breaks.

The harder it is to fix, the more valuable exploitation of the brokenness is.

Inspired by the US electoral college and bitcoin.

1064545434620678144.text:
3/ Something that is robust or anti-fragile will survive or thrive in those black swan events, making them likely to be around longer.

The truly anti-fragile survives anything, and is unlikely to perish.

This framework at least helps measure Lindy lifespan in Black Swan units.

1064544450645377024.text:
2/ When you combine with the anti-fragile framework however, it becomes more useful.

Something that is fragile but has been around for a long time, becomes more rigid and frail as illegible risk builds up.

This risk is exposed in a black swan event, destroying the fragile.

1064543680894128128.text:
1/ My favorite reading of the Lindy effect is along the lines of: “The longer something has been around, the more likely it is to be around in the future, until it’s not.”
